org-entry-head.org-entry-name: African Training and Research Centre in Administration for Development
org-entry-head.alt-name: Centre Africain de Formation et de Recherche Administratives pour le Développement—CAFRAD

address.verbatim-address: Pavillon International, Blvd Mohammed V, POB 1796, 90000 Tangier, Morocco

org-entry.found-date: 1964, with support from UNESCO
org-entry.content-note: undertakes research into administrative problems in Africa and documents results
provides a consultation service for govts and orgs
holds workshops to train senior civil servants
organizes webinars and seminars
org-entry.stats: mems: 36 African countries
org-entry.content-note: publ. Cahiers Africains d'Administration Publique (2 a year)

org-entry.usage: ewyb edio ass mena sasia fea

address.verbatim-address: No. 2, State Guest Houses Complex, Chanakyapuri, New Delhi 110 021, India

org-entry.content-note: aims to promote social change and develop participative co-operation among its mems; provides assistance in evolving an integrated approach, as the crucial pre-requisite in rural Asia and Africa; facilitates exchange of knowledge, best practices and technical assistance concerning rural and agricultural devt among its mems; provides technical and financial support to its mem. countries to undertake pilot projects
organizes training, study visits, deputation of experts
holds international workshops and seminars
awards more than 389 training fellowships at institutes in Bangladesh, Rep. of China, Egypt, India, Rep. of Korea, Malaysia, Nigeria, Pakistan, Philippines, Thailand and Zambia
org-entry.stats: mems: 18 African countries, 14 Asian countries, 2 assoc. mems
org-entry.content-note: publs African-Asian Journal of Rural Development (2 a year), Annual Report , AARDO Newsletter (quarterly)

org-entry-head.alt-name: L’Accord d’Agadir

org-entry.found-date: 2004, upon the adoption of the Agadir Agreement on the establishment of a Free Trade Zone between the Arabic Mediterranean Nations by the govts of Egypt, Jordan, Morocco and Tunisia (implementing a Declaration made in Agadir, Morocco, in May 2001)
org-entry.content-note: the Agreement entered into force in July 2006 and its implementation commenced in March 2007
a Technical Unit to follow up implementation of the Agreement was established in April 2007
a business council was established in Jan. 2016 within the framework of the Agadir Agreement
Lebanon and Palestine joined in April
a Business Forum of the Agadir Agreement and the West African OIC countries was convened in Casablanca, Morocco, in May 2018
org-entry.stats: mems: Egypt, Jordan, Morocco, Tunisia

address.verbatim-address: SHIS-QI 05, Conjunto 16, Casa 21, Lago Sul, Brasília, DF 71615-160, Brazil

org-entry.found-date: 1978, permanent secretariat established 1995
org-entry.content-note: aims to promote the co-ordinated and sustainable devt of the Amazonian territories
there are specialized co-ordinators of environment, health, science technology and education, infrastructure, tourism, transport and communications, and of Indigenous affairs
activities are guided since 2010 by an Amazonian Strategic Cooperation Agenda
issued in 2016, jtly with UNEP , the inaugural Atlas of Hydro-climate Vulnerability of the Amazon Basin

in June 2017 signed a letter of intent with the International Tropical Timber Organization on jtly developing activities aimed at promoting the integrated management and sustainable use of Amazon Basin forests and forest resources
signed a co-operation agreement with UNEP in Jan. 2020 in support of integrated and sustainable transboundary water resources management
co-operates with the Inter-American Development Bank in the implementation of its Amazon Initiative to support subregional sustainable devt, launched by the Bank in March 2021
granted observer status at the UN General Assembly in Dec. 2022

regular meetings of mins responsible for foreign affairs are convened; an Amazon Summit at the level of heads of state or of govt has been held periodically: the 4th such gathering (the 3rd having been held in 2009) was organized in Aug. 2023, in Belém, Pará, Brazil, instigated by that country’s Pres. Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva; the Democratic Rep. of the Congo, Rep. of the Congo, Indonesia, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines were also represented; the summit issued the Declaration of Belém, which urged the strengthening of the org., incl. through more frequent leaders’ meetings, increased co-ordinated social participation by Indigenous peoples, and through the formation of an Amazonian Parliament; a communiqué titled `United for Our Forests—Joint Communiqué of Developing Forest Countries in Belém’ urged increased financial aid from developed states to support the devt and implementation of forest preservation strategies
in Sept. signed a partnership arrangement with the Inter-American Development Bank to strengthen collaboration in support of sustainable devt in the Amazon
org-entry.stats: mems: Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Peru, Suriname, Venezuela

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa
org-entry-head.alt-name: Banque Arabe pour le Développement Economique en Afrique

address.verbatim-address: Al-Amiriya Tower, Al-Olaya District, King Fahd Rd, Bldg No. 7922, Sub no. 4091, 12333 Riyadh, Saudi Arabia

org-entry.found-date: 1973 by mem. states of the Arab League
org-entry.content-note: provides loans and grants to sub-Saharan African countries to finance devt projects

BADEA participates—with the Islamic Development Bank, OPEC Fund, Arab Monetary Fund and other partners—in the Arab Coordination Group, a strategic alliance that was established in 1975, and aims collectively to optimize resources to advance sustainable devt

in Nov. 2020 BADEA, the African Export-Import Bank and the International Islamic Trade Finance Corporation initiated a US $1,500m. Collaborative COVID-19 Pandemic Response Facility, which aimed to support African countries in addressing the pandemic
total assets $5,422m. (31 Dec. 2022)
publs Annual Report , Co-operation for Development (quarterly), studies on Afro-Arab co-operation

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Arab Gulf Programme for the United Nations Development Organizations

address.verbatim-address: 8360 Prince Satam ibn Abdul Aziz-Ar rafiah, Riyadh 12751-4694, Saudi Arabia

org-entry.content-note: provides grants for projects in mother and child care carried out by UN orgs, Arab non-governmental orgs and other int. bodies, and co-ordinates assistance by the nations of the Gulf
financing comes mainly from mem. states, all of which are mems of OPEC
in Dec. 2017 the AGFUND Board of Dirs approved support for 10 devt projects aimed at pursuing the UN’s Sustainable Devt Goals
org-entry.stats: mems: Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, UAE

address.verbatim-address: Menntavegur 1, 101 Reykjavík, Iceland

org-entry.content-note: aims to strengthen dialogue and international focus on the future of the Arctic region
annual assembly held every Oct., in Reykjavik
supported the organization in May 2019 of an Arctic Circle China Forum, held in Shanghai, People’s Republic of China
org-entry.stats: mems: govts, orgs, corporations, universities, think tanks, environmental asscns, and other stakeholders incl. Indigenous communities

address.verbatim-address: Fram Centre, 9296 Tromsø, Norway

org-entry.content-note: aims to promote co-operation among the Arctic States on relevant issues, with the involvement of the Arctic Indigenous communities; permanent Council secretariat established 2013

6 scientific working groups focus on Arctic contaminants; monitoring and assessment; conservation of flora and fauna; emergency prevention, preparedness and response; protection of the marine environment; and sustainable devt; task forces and expert groups may be established for specific work
an Agreement on Enhancing International Arctic Scientific Co-operation, negotiated under the Council’s auspices, entered into force in May 2018

Council ministerial meetings are normally convened every 2 years; the 12th, held in May 2021, in Reykjavík, Iceland, endorsed the Council’s first Strategic Plan for the period 2021-30; the meeting also instructed the Council to advance work on monitoring climate change impacts, adaptation, and mitigation, and approved a Regional Action Plan on Marine Litter in the Arctic
in March 2022, following the Russian military invasion of Ukraine, the Council temporarily suspended all activities and official meetings

the 13th meeting of the Council was held in May 2023, in Salekhard, Russia, at the level of senior Arctic officials who reiterated their commitment to the org.; Norway issued its priority focus areas for its term as Chair.: the oceans; climate and environment; sustainable economic development; and people in the North
org-entry.stats: mems: Arctic States: Canada, Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Russian Fed., Sweden, USA; Indigenous Permanent Participants: Arctic Athabaskan Council, Aleut International Association, Gwich'in Council International, Inuit Circumpolar Council, Russian Association of Indigenous Peoples of the North, Saami Council; 38 observers
org-entry.content-note: chairmanship of the Council rotates every 2 years (mid-2023-mid-2025: Norway)

address.verbatim-address: 35 Heng Mui Keng Terrace, Singapore 119616

org-entry.found-date: 1989, as an informal consultative forum; a permanent secretariat was established in 1993
org-entry.content-note: aims to promote multilateral co-operation on issues of trade liberalization, investment and business facilitation, and to support sustainable economic growth throughout the Asia-Pacific region
an Economic Leaders’ Meeting is held each year (2023: San Francisco, USA, in Nov.)

APEC mins responsible for foreign affairs and for economic affairs also meet annually, while a Senior Officials' Meeting (SOM) convenes regu­larly to co-ordinate and administer APEC's numerous cttees and working gps
org-entry.stats: mems: Australia, Brunei Darussalam, Canada, Chile, People’s Rep. of China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Rep. of Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russian Fed., Singapore, Taiwan (as Chinese Taipei), Thailand, USA, Viet Nam

address.verbatim-address: 35 Heng Mui Keng Terrace, Singapore 119616

org-entry.found-date: 1989, as an informal consultative forum; a permanent secretariat was established in 1993
org-entry.content-note: aims to promote multilateral co-operation on issues of trade liberalization, investment and business facilitation, and to support sustainable economic growth throughout the Asia-Pacific region
an Economic Leaders’ Meeting is held each year (2023: San Francisco, CA, USA, in Nov.)

APEC mins responsible for foreign affairs and for economic affairs also meet annually, while a Senior Officials' Meeting (SOM) convenes regu­larly to co-ordinate and administer APEC's numerous cttees and working gps
org-entry.stats: mems: Australia, Brunei Darussalam, Canada, Chile, People’s Rep. of China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Rep. of Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russian Fed., Singapore, Taiwan (as Chinese Taipei), Thailand, USA, Viet Nam

address.verbatim-address: POB 3226, Kathmandu, Nepal

org-entry.content-note: forum for the production and dissemination of information on sustainable mountain devt, reducing the risk of mountain disasters, economic devt, the elimination of poverty, and cultural heritage
manages the Asia Pacific Mountain Network knowledge-sharing platform
org-entry.stats: mems: 8 regional mem. countries (Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, People’s Rep. of China, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan)

address.verbatim-address: c/o Japan Water Forum, 6th Floor, 5-4 Nihombashi-Hakozaki-cho, Chuo-ku, Tokyo 103-0015, Japan

org-entry.content-note: organized the inaugural Asia-Pacific Water Summit (APWS) in Beppu, Japan in 2007; the 4th APWS was convened in Kumamoto, Japan, in April 2022, on the theme `Water for Sustainable Development—Best Practices and the Next Generation’
publ. Asian Water Development Outlook

address.verbatim-address: 5-7 Sweet Briar Rd, St Clair, POB 660, Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago

org-entry.found-date: 1994 by the govts of the 13 CARICOM countries and Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Suriname and Venezuela
org-entry.content-note: aims to promote economic integration, sustainable devt and co-operation in the region

to undertake concerted action to protect the environment, in particular to preserve the environmental integrity of the Caribbean Sea, which is regarded as the common patrimony of the peoples of the region

and to encourage the UN to designate the Caribbean Sea a `special area’ within the context of sustainable devt (in Dec. 2014 the UN Gen. Assembly adopted Resolution 69/216, in which it recognized the Sea as an area of unique biodiversity with a highly fragile ecosystem, the conservation of which required co-operation from devt partners; the ACS was invited by the Assembly to report to the UN Secretary-General on progress made in the implementation of the resolution; in Dec. 2018 the Gen. Assembly adopted Resolution 73/229 `Towards the Sustainable Development of the Caribbean Sea for Present and Future Generations’)
co-operates in the areas of trade, transport, sustainable tourism, and natural disasters; policy is determined by a Ministerial Council and implemented by a secretariat based in Port of Spain

a Convention Establishing the Sustainable Tourism Zone of the Caribbean entered into force in Nov. 2013 and a Regional Co-operation Agreement in the Area of Natural Disasters entered into force in March 2014
signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the UN World Tourism Organization in Feb. 2014 to strengthen collaboration in promoting sustainable tourism
a ministerial meeting, held in April 2022, approved a 2022-28 Action Plan which determined to strengthen collaboration in support of the sustainable devt of the Greater Caribbean

meetings of heads of state and govt normally take place every 3 years: at the 9th summit meeting, held in May 2023, in Antigua, Guatemala, on the theme `Innovating Integration through the Sustainable Development of the Greater Caribbean’, leaders resolved to promote and implement the 2022-28 Action Plan; the summit was preceded by the 7th International Cooperation Conference of the ACS, focused on generating international donor funding for the sustainable devt of the region

the ACS participated in July 2023 in the 4th Inter-Secretariat Meeting of subregional integration mechanisms, convened at the Latin American Integration Association secretariat, in Montevideo, Uruguay, with a focus on productive chains (the inaugural meeting had been held in 2014)
org-entry.stats: mems: 25 signatory states, 12 assoc. mems

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Association of Development Financing Institutions in Asia and the Pacific (ADFIAP)

address.verbatim-address: Skyland Plaza, 2nd Floor, Sen. Gil J. Puyat Ave, Makati City, Metro Manila, 1200 Philippines

org-entry.content-note: promotes the interests and economic devt of the respective countries of its mem. institutions, through devt financing
org-entry.stats: mems: 90 institutions in 40 countries
org-entry.content-note: publs ADFIAP Newsletter , Advance Magazine (annually), Sustainability Report

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC)

address.verbatim-address: House No. NW (I)-6, Rd No. 53, Gulshan 2, Dhaka 1212, Bangladesh

org-entry.found-date: 1997 as BIST-EC (Bangladesh, India, Sri Lanka, and Thailand Economic Co-operation); present name adopted, after expansion in membership, in 2004
org-entry.content-note: aims to promote co-operation for economic and social progress of the region
inaugural BIMSTEC-BRICS outreach summit convened in Oct. 2016, in Goa, India
the 4th BIMSTEC summit, held in Aug. 2018, in Kathmandu, Nepal, determined to implement institutional reforms aimed at rationalizing areas of co-operation
the inaugural meeting of a new BIMSTEC Permanent Working Committee (BPWC)—comprising senior officials from mem. states, who act as nat. focal points for the org.—was held in Jan. 2019

the 5th BIMSTEC Summit, hosted from Colombo, Sri Lanka, in March 2022, in a hybrid format, adopted a BIMSTEC Master Plan for Transport Connectivity, and a BIMSTEC Charter in Nov. 2022 BIMSTEC mins responsible for agriculture adopted a Plan of Action on Strengthening BIMSTEC Agricultural Cooperation, covering the period 2023-27
org-entry.stats: mems: Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Myanmar, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Thailand

address.verbatim-address: 39 rue de la Régence, 1000 Brussels, Belgium

org-entry.found-date: 1960 to bring about the economic union of Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands
org-entry.content-note: in June 2008 a new Benelux Treaty was adopted to enter into force upon the expiry in 2010 of the treaty establishing the Union; under the new legal framework cross-border co-operation between the mem. states and co-operation within a broader European context were to be advanced
the Union aims to introduce common policies in the field of cross-border co-operation and harmonize standards and intellectual property legislation
a Benelux Organisation for Intellectual Property was established in Sept. 2006
publs Plan Annuel , other papers, statistical reports

address.verbatim-address: Jianguomenwai Ave, China World Tower, No. 1, Rm 2210, Beijing, People’s Republic of China

org-entry.content-note: promotes debate and greater economic integration within Asia and between Asia and other parts of the world
its agenda has expanded to focus on sustainable economic devt, as well as technology innovation, health, education, culture and media
holds annual conference in Boao (2024: in March)
org-entry.stats: mems: some 116 partner cos

org-entry.usage: ewyb edio sacac ass sasia fea eerca
org-entry.content-note: informal grouping of emerging economies; known as BRIC prior to the accession of South Africa in Dec. 2010
during the next 13 years BRICS comprised Brazil, the People’s Rep. of China, the Russian Fed., India, and South Africa
the acronym BRICS was retained following the accession in Jan. 2024 of Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, Saudi Arabia and the UAE; the expanded group represents 45% of the global population
convened an inaugural summit of heads of state and of govt in June 2009, in Yekaterinburg, Russia, at which principles for future co-operation and devt were adopted
regular meetings are convened of mins responsible for foreign affairs and int. relations, finance and economics, security, agriculture, trade, communications and ICT, and health
a BRICS Business Council was est. in March 2013 and a BRICS Women’s Business Alliance was est. in Nov. 2019 (its inaugural meeting was held, in a virtual format, in July 2020)
leaders attending the 6th BRICS summit, held in Fortaleza, Brazil, in July 2014, concluded an accord establishing the New Development Bank (NDB) , which was launched, in Shanghai, China, in July 2015

in Sept. 2018 BRICS mins responsible for communications and ICT resolved to support co-operation between small, micro and medium enterprises in mem. states, and agreed a Partnership on New Industrial Revolution (PartNIR) agenda, which aimed to strengthen co-operation with regard to innovation, digitalization and industrialization; a Digital BRICS Task Force was established to co-ordinate PartNIR activities

China hosted the 14th summit meeting of heads of state and of govt, in June 2022, in a virtual format; the final Summit Declaration included calls for more inclusive global governance, the strengthening of multilateral financial institutions to enhance their capacity to advance global devt objectives, and support for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine to achieve a peaceful solution to the ongoing conflict
the meeting welcomed the launch, in March, of a BRICS Vaccine R&D Center, and urged the establishment of a BRICS Integrated Early Warning System to strengthen public health emergency measures
a BRICS Plus initiative, introduced in 2017, promotes engagement with other emerging economies; the inaugural BRICS Plus Foreign Ministers Dialogue was held in May 2022

in June 2023 a regular meeting of BRICS mins responsible for foreign affairs and international relations called for a `rebalancing’ of the global order, better to represent the world’s multipolarity; the meeting also gave consideration to strengthening the NDB, and to promoting the use in international trade of alternative currencies to the US dollar

the 15th summit meeting, held in Johannesburg, South Africa, in Aug., agreed on an expansion of the grouping, inviting Argentina, Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, Saudi Arabia and the UAE, out of some 23 applicant countries, to join on 1 Jan. 2024
general principles and admission criteria were reportedly agreed by consensus at the meeting, providing for further future expansion

Russia’s Pres. Vladimir Putin participated in the meeting via a video link, in view of an outstanding arrest warrant that had been issued against him, in March, by the International Criminal Court (ICC)

an extraordinary summit meeting was convened, in a virtual format, in Nov. to consider a collective response to the Israeli-Hamas conflict; South Africa’s Pres. Ramaphosa, chairing the meeting, confirmed that the grouping demanded a cessation of hostilities on both sides and that any forced transfer or deportation of Palestinians constituted a crime against international humanitarian law

in Dec. the new Argentine administration of Javier Milei announced that the country would not become a mem. of the grouping as previously anticipated; the other 5 invitees joined as planned on 1 Jan. 2024
granted observer status at the UN General Assembly in Dec. 2018
org-entry.stats: mems: Brazil, People’s Rep. of China, Egypt, Ethiopia, India, Iran, Russian Fed. (Chair. in 2024, position rotates annually), Saudi Arabia, South Africa, UAE

address.verbatim-address: 20 Old Bailey, London, EC4M 7AN, United Kingdom

org-entry.content-note: promotes trade and investment devt between the UK, the Caribbean and Central America

address.verbatim-address: CAREC Unit, 6 ADB Ave, Mandaluyong City, 1550 Metro Manila, Philippines

org-entry.content-note: a subregional alliance supported by several multilateral institutions (the ADB, the EBRD, the IMF, the IDB, UNDP and the World Bank) to promote devt through regional co-operation
supports projects in the following priority areas: transport, energy, trade policy, trade facilitation
org-entry.stats: mems: Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, People’s Rep. of China, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan
org-entry.content-note: publ. Mid-term Review

address.verbatim-address: 42 rue de la Loi, 1040 Brussels, Belgium

org-entry.found-date: 1992, entered into force in 1993
org-entry.content-note: amended, enlarged CEFTA signed Dec. 2006, and entered into force in July 2007 for Albania, North Macedonia, Moldova, Montenegro and Kosovo (represented by the UN Interim Administration in Kosovo), in Aug. of that year for Croatia, Oct. for Serbia, and Nov. for Bosnia and Herzegovina
aims to expand trade and foster investment by monitoring regulation between parties concerned, establishing free trade areas with the recommendation of the European Union

in early 2020 introduced a `green priority lanes’ initiative to facilitate the cross-border flow of essential goods, such as medicines and food, during the COVID-19 crisis; in this respect the CEFTA System on Electronic Exchange of Data (SEED) was upgraded and a CEFTA Coordination Body was established
transitional rules on origin of goods of a stalled Pan-Euro-Mediterranean Convention entered into effect on 1 Feb. 2023
Chair.-in-Office rotates annually (2024: Serbia) and hosts CEFTA Week
org-entry.stats: mems: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Moldova, Monte­negro, North Macedonia, Serbia, UNMIK/Kosovo

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Centre on Integrated Rural Development for Asia and the Pacific (CIRDAP)

address.verbatim-address: Chameli House, 17 Topkhana Rd; GPO Box 2883, Dhaka 1000, Bangladesh

org-entry.content-note: supports integrated rural devt, promotes regional co-operation and organizes international training progs
org-entry.stats: mems: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Fiji, India, Indonesia, Iran, Lao People’s Democratic Rep., Malaysia, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Viet Nam

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Club du Sahel et de l'Afrique de l'Ouest
org-entry-head.alt-name: Sahel and West Africa Club

address.verbatim-address: c/o OECD, 2 rue André Pascal, 75775 Paris, Cedex 16, France

org-entry.found-date: 1977 as Club du Sahel, present name and structure adopted in April 2001
org-entry.content-note: hosted by the OECD , aims to promote and facilitate research, networking and multi-stakeholder dialogue
focuses on support for the effective governance of food security, food systems, regional security and urbanization
org-entry.stats: mems: 15 nat. and int. orgs, 3 observers
org-entry.content-note: publs West African Papers , West African Studies
aims to combat poverty through socioeconomic devt
org-entry.stats: mems: Benin, Ghana, Nigeria, Togo

address.verbatim-address: Old Conference Bldg, 3rd Floor, Roosevelt St, W21K19 Addis Ababa, Ethiopia

org-entry.found-date: 2009, sponsored by the African Union (AU) Commission, African Export-Import Bank, ECA and the AfDB
org-entry.content-note: brings together African stakeholders and policymakers; works with regional and international orgs to address issues relating to security, peace, governance, devt, integration, public health and preventing illicit financial flows (hosts the AU High Level Panel on Illicit Financial Flows)
a CoDA office was established at the AU Commission headquarters, in Addis Ababa, in Jan. 2018
in June 2023 co-organized, in Dakar, Senegal, a conf. on Addressing Illicit Financial Flows and Asset Recovery in the Extractive Industry

address.verbatim-address: POB 596, 52 Ananda Coomaraswamy Mawatha, Colombo 3, Sri Lanka

org-entry.found-date: 1950, as the Colombo Plan for Co-operative Economic and Social Development in Asia and the Pacific, by 7 Commonwealth countries
org-entry.content-note: aims to encourage eco­nomic and social devt in that region, based on principles of partnership and collective effort

the Plan incorporates a Drug Advisory Programme, a Gender Affairs Programme, Capacity Building Programmes, a Programme for Environment and Climate Change (which promotes a One Child One Tree campaign) and the Global Centre for Credentialing and Certification
org-entry.stats: mems: 27 countries
org-entry.content-note: publs Annual Report , Colombo Plan Focus (quarterly)

address.verbatim-address: Bldg 41, 1st Floor, CSIR Campus, Meiring Naude Rd, Brummeria, Pretoria, 0001 South Africa

org-entry.content-note: tripartite co-operation, aiming to advance regional integration through the harmonization of the trade and infrastructure devt programmes of these regional economic communities, was initiated in 2005 (a COMESA-SADC task force having been active during 2001-05); a Tripartite Task Force—led by the Secretaries-General of COMESA and the EAC, and the Executive Secretary of SADC—has convened regularly thereafter

the inaugural Tripartite Summit, organized in Oct. 2008, in Kampala, Uganda, approved a roadmap towards the formation of a single Tripartite FTA (TFTA); an agreement establishing the TFTA was signed in June 2015, by heads of state and government meeting in Sharm el-Sheik, Egypt
in May 2018 EAC-COMESA-SADC chiefs of immigration authorities met to address means of introducing free movement for business people in the TFTA
on 31 July 2020 Tripartite Guidelines for the Movement of Persons, Goods and Services across the Tripartite Region during the COVID-19 Pandemic were approved (based on guidelines developed by COMESA)

the 9th meeting of a Tripartite Sectoral Ministerial Committee was held in March 2023 to review progress on the key pillars of the TFTA: market integration, industrial devt and infrastructure devt (by early 2024 the agreement had been signed by 26 mem. states, and ratified by 11, requiring a further 3 to enter into force)

org-entry-head.alt-name: International Commission of the Congo-Oubangui-Sangha Basin

org-entry.content-note: promotes inland navigation and integrated water resources management along the Congo River watershed
org-entry.stats: mems: Angola, Cameroon, Central African Rep., Democratic Rep. of the Congo, Rep. of the Congo, Gabon

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Communauté Economique des Etats de l'Afrique Centrale
org-entry-head.alt-name: Economic Community of Central African States

address.verbatim-address: BP 2112, Libreville, Gabon

org-entry.found-date: 1983, operational 1 Jan. 1985
org-entry.content-note: aims to promote co-operation between mem. states by abolishing trade restrictions, establishing a common external customs tariff, linking commercial banks, and setting up a devt fund
works to promote regional security

in June 2002 CEEAC heads of state and govt adopted a protocol providing for the establishment of a Council for Peace and Security in Central Africa (including a Defence and Security Commission), as well as a subregional multinational force (FOMAC), and the Early Warning Mechanism of Central Africa
a CEEAC Parliament was inaugurated in Malabo, Equatorial Guinea, in April 2010
the Central African Power Pool (q.v.) was est. in 2003 as a specialized agency of CEEAC
from July 2008-Dec. 2013 deployed the Mission for the Consolidation of Peace in the CAR—MICOPAX
participated from May 2013 in meetings of the International Contact Group on the CAR, and has from Aug. 2016 been part of the successor International Support Group on the CAR

in June 2013 CEEAC participated, with ECOWAS and the Gulf of Guinea Commission, in a regional summit on maritime safety and security, convened in Yaoundé, Cameroon, which adopted a Code of Conduct concerning the Prevention and Repression of Piracy, Armed Robbery against Ships, and Illegal Maritime Activities in West and Central Africa
in Sept. 2014, under the auspices of the 3 orgs, an Interregional Coordination Centre for Maritime Safety and Security in Central and West Africa was inaugurated, in Yaoundé
in 2015 formally adopted the Migration Dialogue for Central African States (MIDCAS)

8th extraordinary session of heads of state and of govt, held in Libreville, in Nov. 2016, expressed support for a CEEAC-AU-UN mediation initiative between the CAR Government and armed groups in support of the demobilization and repatriation process in that country

a jt CEEAC-ECOWAS Summit on Peace, Security, Stability and the Fight against Terrorism and Violent Extremism, convened in July 2018, in Lomé, Togo, determined to formulate a mutual Criminal Cooperation Agreement and to establish a ministerial cttee to follow up decisions on collaboration

in Dec. 2019 CEEAC heads of state and of govt determined to transform the Secretariat of the org. into a Commission, and to introduce a streamlined regional peace and security framework; the new structure was initiated on 1 Sept. 2020

in July 2021, meeting in Brazzaville, Rep. of the Congo, CEEAC heads of state and of govt determined to establish a Luanda, Angola-based Regional Centre for Renewable Energies and Energy Efficiency in Central Africa (CEREEAC); CEREEAC was inaugurated in March 2023

in Aug. 2022 a meeting of the Steering Committee for the Rationalization of Regional Economic Communities in Central Africa (a technical advisory body with participation by representatives of 11 Central African states), convened in Yaoundé, Cameroon, agreed in principle to merge CEEAC, the Communauté Economique et Monétaire de l'Afrique Centrale (CEMAC) and the Economic Community of the Great Lakes Countries (CEPGL) into a single org.

an extraordinary summit convened in Oct. 2022 appointed Pres. Félix Tshisekedi of the Democratic Rep. of the Congo (DRC) as Facilitator of the ongoing political transition in Chad (where, in April 2021, following the killing by rebels of Pres. Idriss Déby, military leaders had installed Déby's son, Gen. Mahamat Déby Itno, as the head of a military council for an 18-month transition period (extended in Oct. 2022 by a further 24 months), pending the organization of national elections

the 22nd regular summit of CEEAC heads of state and of govt summit was hosted by the DRC, in its capital Kinshasa, in Feb. 2023 (Rwanda alleged that it had been excluded from participation by the DRC authorities); the meeting adopted a revised protocol relating to the safety and security of vital maritime interests, as well as a protocol relating to the devt of a sustainable regional blue economy; the CEEAC leaders also determined to postpone the proposed CEEAC-CEMAC-CEPGL merger
the 23rd summit took place in June, in Libreville, Gabon (which assumed the org.’s rotating presidency)

in late June a 1st quadripartite summit was convened under AU auspices, in Luanda, to address the harmonization of ongoing interventions in the DRC, with participation by CEEAC, the EAC , International Conference on the Great Lakes Region and SADC (the `Quadripartite Platform’)

in July a CEEAC delegation, led by the org’s Pres., participated in the 2nd Russia-Africa Summit, held in St Petersburg, Russian Fed.; at the end of Aug. CEEAC strongly condemned the overthrow by the military of longstanding Gabonese Pres. Ali Bongo Ondimba (who claimed to have won 64% of votes in a recent election)

an extraordinary (4th) session of CEEAC heads of state or of govt that was convened in early Sept. suspended Gabon’s participation in the org. and transferred the rotating presidency to Equatorial Guinea
a Meeting of Chiefs of Defence of the Quadripartite was convened in Oct., in Addis Ababa
org-entry.stats: mems: Angola, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Rep., Chad, Rep. of the Congo, Democratic Rep. of the Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Rwanda, São Tomé and Príncipe

org-entry.content-note: aims to strengthen co-operation between signatory states in order to promote their economic, transportation, communications, social and cultural integration and to facilitate conflict resolution and poverty alleviation

partnership agreements have been concluded with the African Union, the European Union, ECOWAS, FAO, CILSS and BADEA

in April 2021 organized a high-level meeting on counter terrorism

the 21st ordinary gathering of the CEN-SAD Executive Council (comprising mem. states’ ministers resp. for foreign affairs), convened in March 2022, in Rabat, Morocco, gave consideration to a strategic plan to cover the period 2022-26
the Sec.-Gen. visited Libya in March 2022 to advance the return of the org. to its Tripoli Headquarters
a meeting of CEN-SAD ministers resp. for youth was convened in Feb. 2023, in Niamey, Niger
org-entry.stats: mems: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Côte d’Ivoire, Djibouti, Egypt, Eritrea, The Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Kenya, Libya, Mali, Mauritania, Morocco, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan, Togo, Tunisia

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership

org-entry.content-note: an initial accord signed by the so-called P4 (Brunei Darussalam, Chile, New Zealand, Singapore) eliminated some 90% of tariffs on trade between mems upon its entry into force in 2006
negotiations on financial services and investment commenced in March 2008, with the participation of the USA
negotiations on an expanded Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement (TPP), to include, additionally, Australia, Malaysia, Peru and Viet Nam, started in March 2010
Canada and Mexico were invited to join the TPP negotiations in June 2012, and Japan joined in April 2013, thus bringing its coverage to almost 40% of the global economy

in Oct. 2015, meeting in Atlanta, USA, mins responsible for trade concluded a draft agreement on the TPP; the agreement was signed formally in Feb. 2016 by the 12 participating states; its implementation required ratification by their legislatures
in Jan. 2017 the new US Administration announced the withdrawal of the USA from the TPP with immediate effect

in Nov. the 11 remaining signatories determined to pursue further negotiations to secure the accord, which was renamed at that time as the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership

the CPTPP was signed on 8 March 2018; it entered into force on 30 Dec., having been ratified by 6 signatory states (Australia, Canada, Japan, Mexico, New Zealand and Singapore); Viet Nam deposited its ratification in Nov. and the Agreement entered into effect for that country on 14 Jan. 2019; it entered into effect for Peru in Sept. 2021, for Malaysia in Nov. 2022, for Chile in Feb. 2023, and for Brunei in July
all CPTPP founding mems are also mems of APEC

the inaugural meeting of a CPTPP Commission, comprising mins and senior officials of all signatory states, was held in Tokyo, Japan, in Jan. 2019; the 2nd meeting was convened in Auckland, New Zealand in Oct., alongside inaugural meetings of 12 specialized cttees
in Sept. 2021 the 5th meeting, hosted by Japan in a virtual format, determined to establish a cttee on electronic commerce
in that month the People’s Rep. of China and the Rep. of China applied to join the CPTPP; Uruguay applied to join the grouping in Dec. 2022

the UK formally signed a Protocol of Accession to the CPTPP in July 2023, at the 7th meeting of the Commission, held in Auckland, New Zealand: pending ratification by the existing mem. states, it was to become the 12th mem. state and 1st non-founding mem.
a Singapore-based CPTPP International Centre provides support on market access, technology and innovation

org-entry-head.alt-name: Entente Council

address.verbatim-address: 01 BP 3734, angle ave Verdier/rue de Tessières, Abidjan 01, Côte d'Ivoire

org-entry.content-note: the Council's Mutual Aid and Loan Guarantee Fund (Fonds ­d'entraide et de garantie des emprunts) was created to finance devt projects, including agricultural projects, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, vocational training centres and research into new sources of energy; a Convention of Assistance and Co-operation was signed in Feb. 1996
supports infrastructure devt in mem. countries
a trilateral task force was est. in 2017 to promote co-operation between the Conseil de l'Entente, ECOWAS and the ACP states
in March 2022 the Exec. Sec. led a delegation to Burkina Faso, to assess the situation there following the military coup that had taken place in Jan.
a project has been initiated to construct a Tour de l’Entente (Entente Tower) in Abidjan

the military coup that usurped power in Niger in Aug. 2023 reportedly prompted tensions in the org’s membership (with Burkina Faso and Togo more tolerant of the Nigerien military regime than Benin and Côte d'Ivoire)
an extraordinary summit was convened in Sept., at which a new Exec. Sec. was appointed
org-entry.stats: mems: Benin, Burkina Faso, Côte d'Ivoire, Niger, Togo
org-entry.content-note: publ. Rapport d'activité (annually)

org-entry.stats: mems: Denmark, Estonia, the European Union, Finland (holding the rotating presidency: 1 July 2023-30 June 2024), Germany, Iceland, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, Poland, Sweden

org-entry.content-note: aims to foster economic co-operation between mems and to strengthen the role of developing countries in the global economy
project areas include trade; agriculture and food security; transportation; industrial devt; energy and minerals; tourism; and health
granted observer status at the UN in Oct. 2014
in April 2015 announced a partnership with UNIDO that aimed to accelerate inclusive, sustainable industrial devt through the promotion of trade capacity building and entrepreneurship in mem. states
the implementation phase of the D-8 Preferential Trade Agreement (signed in 2006) entered into effect on 1 July 2016
a D-8 Charter entered into force on 1 Sept. 2017
the 9th summit meeting, convened in Oct. in İstanbul, decided to establish a D-8 Project Support Fund, a D-8 Research and Development Centre, and a Hamadan, Iran-based D-8 University

the 10th summit meeting, hosted by Bangladesh in April 2021, adopted a D-8 Decennial Roadmap for 2020-30, which included the goal (to be achieved by 2030) of increasing the volume of intra-D-8 trade to 10% of the organization’s total trade; phase 1 of the Roadmap, covering 2020-22, covered the devt of new projects, phase 2 (2023-27) covered their implementation, and under phase 3 (2028-30) they were to be reviewed
a single card payment system (the `DP8’) has been envisaged, with the aim of facilitating intra-D-8 commerce
org-entry.stats: mems: Bangladesh, Egypt, Indonesia, Iran, Malaysia, Nigeria, Pakistan, Türkiye

address.verbatim-address: POB 1096, Arusha, Tanzania

org-entry.found-date: 2001, following the adoption of a treaty on political and economic integration (signed in Nov. 1999) by the heads of state of Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda, replacing the Permanent Tripartite Commission for East African Co-operation (f. 1993) and reviving the former East African Community (f. 1967, dissolved 1977); Rwanda and Burundi formally became mems of the Community on 1 July 2007, Sudan was admitted in March 2016
org-entry.content-note: initial areas for co-operation were to be trade and industry, security, immigration, transport and communi­cations, and promotion of investment
further objectives were the elimination of trade barriers and ensuring the free movement of people and capital within the grouping
a customs union came into effect on 1 Jan. 2005
an East African Legislative Assembly and an East African Court of Justice were inaugurated in 2001
in April 2006 heads of state agreed that negotiations on a common market would commence in July; the Protocol on the Establishment of the EAC Common Market entered into force on 1 July 2010
the 15th ordinary summit, held in Kampala, Uganda, in Nov. 2011, signed a protocol on the establishment of an East African Monetary Union which envisaged a single currency

a progress report on the establishment of an East African Federation was considered at an extraordinary summit meeting, held in April 2014, which then instructed the Council to initiate a process of drafting a Constitution
a Regional Vision for Socioeconomic Transformation and Development (Vision 2050), was launched in Aug. 2015

from late 2015 President Museveni of Uganda, on behalf of the EAC, led an Inter-Burundi Dialogue with participation by Burundi stakeholders; in March 2016 the EAC appointed the (late) fmr President of Tanzania, Benjamin Mkapa, as the Facilitator of the Dialogue, under Museveni’s guidance; an extraordinary EAC summit convened in Dec. adopted a roadmap to guide the negotiations process; the process was supported by the AU and by the fmr Office of the Special Envoy of the UN Secretary-General in Burundi; the Inter-Burundi Dialogue talks were suspended in mid-2019, reportedly owing to continuing intransigence by the Burundian authorities; a general election was held in Burundi in May 2020
an EAC e-passport was launched at the 17th ordinary summit meeting, held in March 2016, and was issued from 1 Jan. 2017
in Nov. 2017 an EAC Energy Security Policy Framework was adopted
EAC has since 2005 participated in the COMESA-EAC-SADC Tripartite Secretariat , with a view to advancing regional co-operation
in March 2014 signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Economic Community of the Great Lakes Countries to strengthen co-operation between the orgs and enhance regional integration

negotiations on an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) with the European Union were concluded in Oct. 2014; upon entry into force this was to provide immediate duty- and quota-free access for all EAC exports to the EU market, and a gradual, partial opening of the EAC market for EU exports
in Feb. 2019 EAC heads of state agreed that each mem. state might sign and pursue implementation of the EPA without full approval of the grouping

the regular 2021 summit meeting convened, in a virtual format, in Feb., directed the Council to undertake a verification mission to the Democratic Rep. of the Congo (DRC) with regard to its membership application; the mission reported its findings to an extraordinary summit, held in Dec., which upheld the application; the DRC was admitted as the EAC’s 7th mem. in March 2022

an inaugural EAC Head of States Conclave on the DRC, held in April, in Nairobi (launching an EAC `Nairobi Process’ on the DRC), invited armed groups active in the DRC to participate in an EAC-mediated dialogue; in June EAC heads of state agreed to deploy a regional force (the EAC Regional Force—EACRF) to eastern areas of the DRC, tasked with supporting efforts to restore and maintain peace and security
the 5th EAC Arts and Culture Festival (JAMAFEST) was held in Sept., in Bujumbura, Burundi

in late June 2023 a quadripartite summit was convened under AU auspices to address the harmonization of ongoing interventions in the DRC, with participation by the EAC, ICGLR , SADC , and Communauté Economique des Etats de l'Afrique Centrale (the `Quadripartite Platform’)
the 22nd extraordinary EAC summit meeting, held in early Sept., in Nairobi, extended the EACRF’s mandate by a further 3 months (until 8 Dec.)
a Meeting of Chiefs of Defence of the Quadripartite was convened in Oct., in Addis Ababa
in Nov. a meeting of heads of state and govt determined not to extend the mandate beyond Dec., and to withdraw EAC troops; Somalia acceded as the group’s eighth mem. at the meeting
org-entry.stats: mems: Burundi, Democratic Rep. of the Congo, Kenya, Rwanda, Somalia, South Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Economic Community of the Great Lakes Countries

address.verbatim-address: POB 58, Gisenyi, Rwanda

org-entry.content-note: 4 CEPGL specialized agencies were established: a regional electricity co (SINELAC) at Bukavu, Democratic Rep. of the Congo (DRC)
an energy centre at Bujumbura, Burundi
the Institute of Agronomic and Zootechnical Research, Gitega, Burundi
and the Banque de Développement des Etats des Grands Lacs at Goma, DRC

in March 2014 signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the East African Community to strengthen co-operation between the orgs and enhance regional integration; and in Feb. 2016 concluded an MOU with COMESA focused on economic integration, and peace and security

in April 2018 the Exec. Sec. urged mem. states to invest financially in the org. and to initiate a renaissance of CEPGL activities, noting that the last meeting of heads of state had been held in 2007 and the last ministerial session in 2014

in Aug. 2022 a meeting of the Steering Committee for the Rationalization of Regional Economic Communities in Central Africa (a technical advisory body with participation by representatives of 11 Central African states), convened in Yaoundé, Cameroon, agreed in principle to merge CEPGL, the Communauté Economique des Etats de l'Afrique Centrale (CEEAC) and the Communauté Economique et Monétaire de l'Afrique Centrale into a single org.; however, a summit of CEEAC leaders convened in Feb. 2023 determined that the proposed merger should be postponed
org-entry.stats: mems: Burundi, Democratic Rep. of the Congo, Rwanda

address.verbatim-address: Moscow, Russian Federation

org-entry.found-date: 2015, replacing the former Eurasian Economic Community (EurAsEC, f. 2000)
org-entry.content-note: in Oct. 2007 EurAsEC leaders approved the legal basis for establishing a new customs union, initially to comprise Belarus, Kazakhstan and Russia; this entered into formal existence on 1 Jan. 2010; in Dec. the heads of state of Belarus, Kazakhstan and Russia signed several agreements aimed at finalizing the establishment of a planned Common Economic Space (CES; this entered into effect on 1 Jan. 2012), and, in Nov. 2011, they signed a declaration on Eurasian economic integration and adopted a roadmap outlining integration processes aimed at creating the EAEU, to be based on the Customs Union and CES
in May 2014 the heads of state of Russia, Belarus and Kazakhstan signed a treaty establishing the EAEU
agreements to include Armenia and Kyrgyzstan in the Union were initialled in Oct. and Dec., respectively
the Union entered into effect on 1 Jan. 2015
in July 2016 the EAEU ratified a free trade agreement with Viet Nam
a new Agreement on the Customs Code of the EAEU was signed in Nov. and adopted by the Supreme Council in Dec.; this entered into force on 1 Jan. 2018
in Dec. 2016 mem. states agreed to initiate negotiations on free trade agreements with Egypt, India, Iran and Singapore
a common EAEU pharmaceutical market was launched in May 2017
in May 2018 an agreement on co-operation was concluded between the EAEU and the People's Rep. of China

the Supreme Eurasian Economic Council (`Supreme Council') comprises heads of state and gathers at least once a year (Chair. in 2023: Russian Fed.); the Eurasian Intergovernmental Council consists of the heads of govt of mem. states, and meets at least twice a year; the Eurasian Economic Commission (EEC) acts as a permanent regulatory body; a permanent EAEU Court is based in Minsk, Belarus
org-entry.stats: mems: Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russian Fed.

address.verbatim-address: FOCAC Follow-up Committee, 2 Chaoyangmen Nandajie, Chaoyang District, 100701 Beijing, People’s Republic of China

org-entry.content-note: the inaugural FOCAC ministerial conf. (providing a formal framework for co-operation between the People's Republic of China and African states) was held in Oct. 2000
subsequently confs have been held every 3 years

the 8th FOCAC ministerial meeting, held in late Nov. 2021, in Dakar, Senegal, adopted a China-Africa Cooperation Vision 2035, the Dakar Action Plan, under which 9 progs were to be implemented during 2022-24 (the first phase of Vision 2035), the Sino-African Declaration on Climate Change, and a general Declaration; the Dakar Action Plan included a medical and health prog., under which, inter alia, China was to donate 600m. further COVID-19 vaccine doses to Africa, and also to provide 400m. doses through jt Chinese-African production; poverty reduction, agricultural, and trade and investment progs; a digital innovation prog.; green initiatives; capacity building support; cultural initiatives; and a peace and security prog. (which was to include military assistance to the African Union—AU); a reduced Chinese financial commitment, totalling US $40,000m., was made for 2022-24, compared with $60,000m. in 2019-21 (concerns over some African nations’ debt dependency on China had been raised in recent years)

themed `Deepen China-Africa Partnership and Promote Sustainable Development to Build a China-Africa Community with a Shared Future in the New Era’, the 8th FOCAC emphasized Africa-China co-operation in aligning synergies between China’s Belt and Road Initiative, the AU’s Agenda 2063, the UN’s 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, and the national devt strategies of African states
the 7th China-Africa Business Forum was staged alongside the 2021 conf.

address.verbatim-address: United Nations Secretariat Bldg, Rm S-0518, New York, NY 10017, USA

org-entry.found-date: 1964 by the 77 signatory states of the Joint Declaration of the Seventy-Seven Countries (the G77 retains its original name, owing to its historic significance, although its membership has expanded)
org-entry.content-note: the inaugural ministerial meeting, held in Algiers, Algeria, in Oct. 1967, adopted the Charter of Algiers as a basis for G77 co-operation

subsequently, G77 Chapters were established with liaison offices in Geneva (UNCTAD), Nairobi (UNEP), Paris (UNESCO), Rome (FAO/IFAD), Vienna (UNIDO), and the Group of 24 (G24) in Washington, DC (IMF/World Bank)

as the largest intergovernmental org. of developing states in the UN, the G77 aims to enable developing nations to articulate and promote their collective economic interests and to improve their negotiating capacity within the UN system
China participates closely with the grouping, leading to meetings being held and declarations issued as the G77+China
an inaugural South Summit, bringing together all G77 heads of state and govt, was convened in Havana, Cuba, in April 2000; a 2nd South Summit was held in Doha, Qatar, in June 2005
in Sept. 2006 G77 mins responsible for foreign affairs, and the People's Rep. of China, endorsed the establishment of a Consortium on Science, Technology and Innovation for the South

the G77 approves funds allocated through the Perez-Guerrero Trust Fund for South-South Cooperation (PGTF, f. 1983); during 1986-2023 some 384 projects, with a cumulative value of US $16.2m., were approved through the PGTF
an annual meeting of G77 foreign ministers is held at the start (in Sept.) of the regular session of the UN General Assembly
an Intergovernmental Follow-up and Coordination Committee on South-South Cooperation meets every 2 years
periodic sectoral ministerial meetings are organized in preparation for UNCTAD sessions and prior to the UNIDO and UNESCO General Conferences, and with the aim of promoting South-South co-operation
other special ministerial meetings are also convened periodically
a summit meeting was convened in Havana, Cuba, in Sept. 2023
the 3rd South Summit was held in Kampala, Uganda, in Jan. 2024, on the theme `Leaving No One Behind’
org-entry.stats: mems: 134 countries, plus the People’s Rep. of China
org-entry.content-note: chairmanship rotates annually on a regional basis (2024: Uganda)

projects include tuna fishing devt, protection and management of environmental resources and strengthening of meteorological services
tariff reduction is also envisaged
an Anti-Piracy Unit was established within the secretariat in 2011
organizes an annual regional trade fair
participates with the Caribbean Community and the Secretariat of the Pacific Regional Environment Programme in a Climate Resilient Islands Partnership
during 2020-24 was co-ordinating an EU-sponsored Port Security and Safety of Navigation in Eastern and Southern Africa and the Indian Ocean initiative
org-entry.stats: mems: the Comoros, France (representing the French Overseas Department of Réunion), Madagascar, Mauritius, Seychelles

org-entry.content-note: f. 1997 as the Indian Ocean Rim Association for Regional Co-operation, present name adopted in 2013

aims to promote the sustained and balanced devt of the region and of its mem. states and to create common ground for regional economic co-operation, inter alia, through trade, investment, infrastructure, tourism, and science and technology
the 3rd IORA Ministerial Blue Economy Conference (BEC-3) was held in Sept. 2019
the inaugural Leaders’ summit meeting was held in Jakarta, Indonesia, in March 2017
IORA working groups on maritime safety and security and on the blue economy held inaugural meetings in Aug. and Dec. 2019, respectively
9th Indian Ocean Dialogue (IOD): May 2023, in Zanzibar, Tanzania
an IORA Action Plan on Maritime Safety and Security was being implemented during 2022-26

org-entry.content-note: launched in May 2022 as an initiative of the USA; focused on the following four pillars: Connected Economy (covering fair and resilient trade in the areas of labour, environment and climate, digitalization, agriculture, transparency and regulatory practices, competition policy, and trade facilitation); Resilient Economy (supply chain resilience); Clean Economy (infrastructure, clean energy and decarbonization); and Just Economy (taxation and anti-corruption structures)

address.verbatim-address: BP 727, N'Djamena, Chad

org-entry.content-note: promotes co-operation in developing the Lake Chad region and the settlement of regional disputes, water resources management, and environmental resources management

in March 2014 LCBC mins responsible for defence, and their counterpart in Benin, agreed to develop a concept of operations for a Multinational Joint Task Force, to combat arms trafficking, terrorism and cross-border attacks in the sub-region (with particular reference to the terrorist activities of the militant northern Nigeria-based grouping Boko Haram, and ongoing violent conflict in the Central African Rep.)

in Oct. an extraordinary meeting of Commission heads of state (plus Benin) agreed to reinforce jt intelligence and operational capabilities; to put in place a collective border surveillance mechanism; and promptly to develop a subregional common defence strategy; the co-ordinated deployment of national Task Force units commenced in late 2015 (the legal modalities of the collective military co-operation were authorized by the AU Peace and Security Council in Jan. of that year)
in 2018 the LCBC and UNESCO initiated a programme (known as BIOPALT) aimed at preserving the biosphere and heritage of Lake Chad

in May 2018 the inaugural meeting of governors of territories bordering Lake Chad established a Lake Chad Basin Governors’ Forum, to advance collective efforts to promote peace and sustainable devt regionally

in Aug. an LCBC-AU ministerial conf., held in Abuja, adopted a Regional Stabilization, Recovery and Resilience Strategy for Areas Affected by Boko Haram in the Lake Chad Basin Region; in July 2019 a Regional Stabilization Facility for Lake Chad was launched by UNDP in support of the initiative
in March 2022 adopted a regional action plan to support the implementation of the Regional Stabilization, Recovery and Resilience Strategy during 2022-24
in May 2023 co-organized, with the World Bank, the Second Annual International Forum on the Development of the Lake Chad Region, in Niamey, Niger
the 4th Lake Chad Basin Governors’ Forum was convened in July, in N’Djamena
at that time it was reported that 1,038 schools across mem. states were not operating owing to continuing security challenges
convenes an annual regular summit of heads of state
org-entry.stats: mems: Cameroon, Central African Rep., Chad, Libya, Niger, Nigeria; observers: Egypt, Democratic Rep. of the Congo, Rep. of Congo, Sudan

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

address.verbatim-address: 2 rue André-Pascal, 75775 Paris Cedex 16, France

org-entry.found-date: 1961, replacing the Organisation for European Economic Co-operation (f. 1948)
org-entry.content-note: serves as a forum for governments to discuss, develop and attempt to co-ordinate their economic and social policies

aims to promote policies designed to achieve the highest level of sustainable economic growth, employment and increase in the standard of living, while maintaining financial stability and democratic government, and the expansion of world trade

in Oct. 2021, in the context of an OECD/G20 Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) initiative introduced in 2013, 136 countries and jurisdictions (accounting for more than 90% of global GDP, and including all OECD and G20 member states), formally approved an updated final Statement on the Two-Pillar Solution to Address the Tax Challenges Arising from the Digitalisation of the Economy, providing for multinational enterprises to be subject to a minimum 15% tax rate
org-entry.stats: mems: 38 states, incl. Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica and Mexico

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Organisation of African, Caribbean and Pacific States

address.verbatim-address: 16 Place Charles Rogier, Saint-Josse-ten-Noode, 1210 Brussels, Belgium

org-entry.found-date: 1975, in accordance with the founding Georgetown Agreement, as the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States, with the aim of promoting devt in mem. states; in Dec. 2019 the 9th summit of ACP heads of state and govt, held in Nairobi, Kenya, endorsed revisions to the Georgetown Agreement that, inter alia, renamed the org., and entered into effect on 5 April 2020
org-entry.content-note: in Sept. 2018 the (then) ACP Group initiated negotiations with the EU on drafting a successor agreement to the 2003 Cotonou Agreement governing EU-ACP devt co-operation, which was scheduled to expire at the end of Feb. 2020 (in turn, the Cotonou Agreement had seceded the 1975 Lomé Conventions as the mutual co-operation basis)
in Feb. 2020 both sides agreed to prolong the existing Agreement
in Dec. 2020, meeting virtually, the OACPS Council of Ministers endorsed a new draft Partnership Agreement with the EU; a finalized version of the text was initialled in April 2021

in July 2023 the European Council adopted a decision that paved the way for the signature and then provisional application of the agreement; it was signed at a ceremony held in Nov., in Apia, Samoa; the provisional application of the so-called Samoa Agreement commenced on 1 Jan. 2024
the OACPS Council of Ministers convenes two ordinary annual sessions; sectoral ministerial meetings on trade and on culture are also held
the 10th OACPS summit meeting of heads of state and govt was convened in Luanda, Angola, in Dec. 2022; a Business Forum was held at the same time
org-entry.stats: mems: 48 African, 16 Caribbean and 15 Pacific states

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Organization for the Development of the Senegal River
org-entry-head.alt-name: Organisation pour la mise en valeur du fleuve Sénégal—OMVS

address.verbatim-address: Immeuble OMVS, Rocade Fann Bel-air Cerf volant, Dakar, Senegal

org-entry.content-note: aims to promote the use of the Senegal river for hydroelectricity, irrigation and navigation

the Djama dam in Senegal provides a barrage to prevent salt water from moving upstream, and the Manantali dam in Mali is intended to provide a reservoir for irrigation of about 375,000 ha of land and for production of hydroelectricity and provision of year-round navigation for ocean-going vessels
2 cos were formed in 1997 to manage the dams: Société de gestion de l'énergie de Manantali and Société de gestion et d'exploitation du barrage de Djama
OMVS is developing a €990m. dam and hydroelectric plant at Koukoutamba, Guinea, and the Gourbassi hydroelectric project on the Falémé River, at the Senegal-Malian frontier
implements a river navigation project
maintains an Environment Observatory
a Conf. of heads of state or govt was convened, in a virtual format, in July 2023, following which Guinea announced it was suspending its participation in the grouping
org-entry.stats: mems: Guinea, Mali, Mauritania, Senegal

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation

address.verbatim-address: Darüşşafaka Cad., Seba Center İş Merkezi, No: 45, Kat 3, Istinye 34460 İstanbul, Türkiye

org-entry.found-date: 1992 as the Black Sea Economic Cooperation (name changed on entry into force of BSEC Charter on 1 May 1999)
org-entry.content-note: aims to strengthen regional co-operation, particularly in the field of economic devt

the following institutions have been established within the framework of BSEC: a Parliamentary Assembly (established in 1993), a Business Council (1992), a Black Sea Trade and Development Bank (inaugurated in 1998), a BSEC Co-ordination Centre, and a Black Sea International Studies Centre (opened in 1998)

regional security was disrupted in the following month by the Russian Fed.’s invasion of Ukraine; in July negotiations held in İstanbul under the auspices of the UN and Türkiye (which had assumed a mediatory role between Russia and Ukraine) culminated in the conclusion by Russia and Ukraine of the UN-backed Black Sea Grain Initiative (BSGI), enabling the resumption of exports of grain, sunflower oil and other essential goods from Odesa and two other Ukrainian Black Sea ports (that had hitherto been blockaded by Russia), and at facilitating fertilizer and grain exports from Russia (which had been subjected to punitive sanctions)

under the agreement UN, Turkish and Ukrainian personnel were to monitor the loading of grain at Ukrainian ports, and an İstanbul-based UN-Türkiye-Russia-Ukraine joint co-ordination centre was to supervise the safe navigation of loaded vessels through the Black Sea exportation corridors towards the Bosphorus Strait; the centre was also to inspect ships entering Ukraine, to ensure that they were not carrying military weaponry; Russia and Ukraine agreed to desist from attacking any of the commercial vessels or ports covered by the BSGI

extensions to the BSGI were subsequently agreed; however, on 17 July 2023 the initiative lapsed, the Russian authorities having refused to renew it, claiming that commitments made to Russia had not been fulfilled

in July 2023 the Turkish Chair. designated as its priority sectoral focus areas during July-Dec.: ensuring the full resumption of collaboration among mem, states; updating the org.’s Economic Agenda; activating its Project Development Fund; and regenerating the Business Council
mems: Albania, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Georgia, Greece, Moldova, North Macedonia, Romania, Russian Fed., Serbia, Türkiye, Ukraine
org-entry.stats: 13 countries incl. Egypt, Israel and Tunisia have been granted observer status; 5 countries incl. Iran have been granted sectoral dialogue partnership status

org-entry-head.alt-name: Alianza del Pacífico

org-entry.content-note: the Presidents of Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru, meeting in Antofagasta, Chile, signed the Pacific Alliance Framework Agreement, formally establishing the Alliance, in June 2012
this entered into effect in July 2015

objectives included the establishment of a pan-Latin American stock exchange; the elimination of visa restrictions for citizens of mem. countries; the opening of jt export promotion offices and diplomatic missions; and co-operation to eliminate import duties and country-of-origin rules between mem. states

an agreement to eliminate trade tariffs was concluded at the 2013 meeting of heads of state, held in Santiago de Cali, Colombia, in May; the meeting also resolved to establish a Pacific Alliance Partnership Fund
in Feb. 2014 heads of state, meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, signed an agreement to eliminate 92% of trade tariffs on goods and services

an Additional Protocol to the Pacific Alliance Framework Agreement, establishing the Pacific Alliance Free Trade Zone, entered into effect on 1 May 2016: some 92% of tariffs on intra-Alliance trade were consequently to be removed; in June a Regional Observatory for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises was established
in April 2017 a roadmap towards greater Alliance-MERCOSUR co-operation was agreed at a ministerial meeting convened in Buenos Aires, Argentina
negotiations on free trade agreements (FTAs) with Australia, Canada, New Zealand and Singapore were initiated in 2017
in July 2018 heads of state attending the first highest-level MERCOSUR-Pacific Alliance meeting signed a letter of intent on the future devt of a regional FTA

the 15th summit meeting was convened, in a virtual format, in Dec. 2020; heads of state declared their commitment to work together to counter the social and economic impacts of COVID-19; they also issued presidential declarations on gender equality and on the devt of the regional digital market
a Pacific Alliance-Singapore FTA was signed at the 16th summit meeting, held in Bahía Málaga, Colombia, in Jan. 2022
summit meetings scheduled to be held in Nov., in Mexico City, and in Dec., in Lima, were postponed as a result of political conflict in Peru

in June 2023 Mexico declined to transfer the pro tempore presidency to Peru, owing to its concerns regarding the legitimacy of the political leadership in that country; Chile temporarily assumed the role until an agreement was reached to transfer it, in early Aug., to Peru

technical groups active in 2024 covered, inter alia , innovation co-operation, digital agenda, culture, devt and social inclusion, education, environment, gender, labour, movement of people, SMEs, tourism, trade facilitation and customs co-operation, and (ad hoc) fishing; there was also a committee on market access and a sub-committee on services and capital
org-entry.stats: mems: Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru; Associated State mem.: Singapore; 63 observer states

org-entry.content-note: USMCA (also known as the Canada-United States-Mexico Agreement—CUSMA/Accord Canada-États-Unis-Mexique—ACEUM, and the Tratado entre México, Estados Unidos y Canadá—T-MEC) entered into force on 1 July 2020

the initial version of the accord, designed to replace the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA, which had been in force since 1 Jan. 1994), was signed on 30 Nov. 2018; a revised USMCA was adopted by the participant states on 10 Dec. 2019—this was ratified by Mexico on 12 Dec., signed into law by US Pres. Trump at the end of Jan. 2020, and ratified by Canada in mid-March
USMCA was to be subject to a review process in 2026, and was to expire in 2036

it has provisions covering agricultural and industrial products; labour standards; environmental protections; sanitary and phytosanitary standards; transparency requirements; the digital economy; and intellectual property protections (including for certain medicinal drugs); a pre-existing (under NAFTA) trilateral dispute resolution process was retained under the new arrangement

a dispute settlement panel est. in May 2021 at the request of the USA and tasked with reviewing Canada’s allocation of dairy tariff-rate quotas (which were deemed by the USA to undermine the range of its dairy exports to consumers in Canada) ruled in favour of the USA in Jan. 2022
the inaugural USMCA Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise Dialogue was convened in April 2022, in San Antonio, Texas, USA
the value of intra-USMCA trade in goods and services amounted to nearly US $1,200,000m. in 2021

address.verbatim-address: 91-93 route de la Capite, 1223 Cologny/Geneva, Switzerland

org-entry.content-note: convenes an annual meeting in Davos-Klosters, Switzerland; the 54th took place in Jan. 2024, and addressed four themes: Achieving Security and Cooperation in a Fractured World; Creating Growth and Jobs for a New Era; AI as a Driving Force for the Economy and Society; and A Long-Term Strategy for Climate, Nature and Energy
comprises commercial interests gathered on a non-partisan basis, under the stewardship of the Swiss Govt, with the aim of improving society through economic devt

organizes the following programmes: Technology Pioneers; Women Leaders; a Network of Global Future Councils; New Champions; and Young Global Leaders; and aims to mobilize the resources of the global business community in the implementation of initiatives including the Global Health Initiative, the Disaster Relief Network, and the G20/International Monetary Reform Project
organizes an Annual Meeting on Cybersecurity (2023: in Nov.)
compiles a Global Competitiveness Index

in 2018 the Forum opened a Centre for the Fourth Industrial Revolution, in San Francisco, CA, USA, as a focal point for international dialogue regarding the impact of advanced technologies, and a Centre for Cybersecurity, located in Geneva, Switzerland
in Jan. 2019 launched a Global Humanitarian Action Executive Alliance

the Essential Digital Infrastructure and Services Network (EDISON) Alliance was initiated by the Forum in Feb. 2021, to promote cross-sectoral collaboration in advancing equitable global access to the digital economy
the Forum is governed by a Foundation Board, an advisory International Business Council, and an administrative Managing Board
org-entry.stats: regular mems: reps of 1,000 leading commercial cos in 56 countries worldwide; selected mem. cos taking a leading role in the movement's activities are known as `partners'
org-entry.content-note: publ. The Global Competitiveness Report
